p: 71 patients were treated in the standard setting (SS) of the outpatient clinic of a tertiary care center (Wilhelminen Hospital Vienna) and 74 PWIDs on OST received antiviral therapy with G/P at their pharmacy (n = 72) or at the Ambulatorium Suchthilfe Wien (n = 2)â€“always concomitantly with their OST according to the concept of DOT ( Table 1, Fig 1). As compared to the SS-group, patients in the DOT-group were significantly younger and the percentage of men was slightly higher, as was the prevalence of GT1a. Most PWIDs included in the DOT-group were characterized by a very poor socioeconomic status: n = 64 (86.5%) were unemployed, n = 39 (52.7%) had no own housing, n = 49 (66.2%) had previously been imprisoned and only n = 29 (39.2%) reported to be living in a stable relationship; in addition, relevant psychiatric comorbidity was present in all of them; ongoing intravenous drug use was reported in n = 50 (67.6%) ( Table 2). As compared to the DOT-group, the percentage of patients with employment, own housing and without a history of imprisonment was significantly higher in the SS-group.
